awd_titl_txt: Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program for University of South Florida Science Majors
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of South Florida (USF), with support from the Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship program, will implement a model for encouraging science majors to enter an attractive, viable and rewarding career pathway to teaching at the secondary level through collaboration among the USF Colleges of Education and Arts and Sciences, and the Hillsborough County Public Schools.  Thirty-six biology, chemistry, geosciences and physics majors will receive scholarships to complete a 5-year Accelerated Study Program leading to a bachelor's degree in the Sciences and a Master of Arts in Teaching (MAT) degree with certification in secondary science. The project will also support 20 summer interns (freshman and sophomore science majors).  Under the guidance of science education faculty, these interns will conduct research on how to develop professional learning communities, and to engage teachers and have them adopt the practices described in the Next Generation Science Standards.  

Student preparation will emphasize teaching science using reform, evidence-based practices; acquiring a deep understanding of the nature of science; engaging and helping others engage in good practices; special strategies to reach culturally and linguistically diverse learners (i.e., English language learners, Hispanic and African-American students, and students of low socio-economic status); and building relationships among all USF Noyce scholars that lead to long-term peer support through professional learning communities. Furthermore, the project will utilize a cohort model with an intentional support network infrastructure designed to encourage mentorship, collaborations and success as candidates make the transition from students to teachers through the induction years. 

Ultimately, the project will supply high-need schools with exemplary science teachers who deeply understand how to implement research-based practices in response to student, district, and community sociocultural characteristics and needs.  The investigators will conduct research on the development of professional learning communities and their implementation, as well as the ways in which the interns learn to engage in the science practices described in the Next Generation Science Standards. Findings from this work are expected to be of benefit to the broader STEM teacher preparation field. In addition, the evaluation will measure the effectiveness of the program, the qualification and effectiveness of the scholars and their retention rate.

por.por_cntn:
The Robert Noyce Scholarship for Science Majors Program at the University of South Florida began in Fall 2014 and ended in August 2021. This project was successful in establishing and implementing well-trained and high-quality STEM field university students to teach middle and high school science in the USF service area. The fundamental goal of the USF Robert Noyce Scholarship Program to prepare STEM majors and career changers to become highly effective secondary science teachers in local high-needs school districts was accomplished by providing coursework and ongoing support to foster success in the early stages of their teaching careers. The objectives over the years were to: 1) ensure the preparation of highly qualified science teachers through three programs (Science Teachers Accelerated Masters Program - STAMP, Research in STEM Education - RISE Summer Internship, and Master of Arts in Teaching - MAT scholarship), 2) provide students in science majors an attractive, viable, and rewarding career path in secondary science teaching, and 3) facilitate the efficacy of science education in high-needs districts by supplying exemplary science teachers who deeply understand how to implement research-based, culturally responsive (Gay, 2000; Ladson-Billings, 1995) practices in response to student, district, and community sociocultural characteristics and demands. Ultimately, the Project Team exceeded its objectives.

The Project Team was involved throughout the duration of the program, providing oversight,  guidance, feedback, support, and recommendations. Scholars engaged in professional reading, discussion, and reflection about culturally-responsive science teaching, inquiry as mindset, and evidence-based teaching. Through ongoing interaction, the Project Team supported the preparation of the scholars for upcoming challenges that will likely emerge within their high-needs classroom settings. They participated in frequent opportunities to share their experiences and build community by attending and presenting at conferences and workshops locally and throughout the nation.

Through the formal and informal project activities, scholars built a strong, trusting community that fostered reflection about their beliefs and sharing of diverse perspectives. The scholars valued the environment created by the project and the learning opportunities it provided. Scholars who completed the program and have been teaching in the local district continued to be invited to participate in workshops, socials, and other activities organized by the project, giving them the opportunity to share their experiences with other students and teachers.  

The Project Team recognized and addressed a number of challenges, particularly with regard to COVID-19. They quickly shifted to incorporate the data collected and lessons learned based on the emergence of new insights about the needs of the public school students as a result of COVID-19. Throughout, the Project Team continuously met to support the scholars? needs through regular reflection, reassessment, and shift in methods for teacher preparation.

Overall, the project has awarded a total of 25 scholarships to produce certified science and math teachers to teach in schools in high-needs districts. Many of the graduates have continued to stay connected and maintain the supportive connections provided by the project through a private online network. The USF Noyce project proved to be a successful investment of National Science Foundation funding for the recruitment and preparation of high-quality science teachers prepared to teach in high-needs districts.

 


Last Modified: 11/05/2021
Modified by: Allan Feldman
